hawaiian_text: Lālau akula ‘o Puali‘i i ke ko‘ilipi a hele akula ā  hiki i waena ā loa‘a o Nāmakaokapāo‘o e kunu ana  i nā ‘au ‘uala āna ‘ehā, i luna o ke ahi. ‘Ike maila nā  keiki a pau loa, holo akula lākou ā kū maila ma kahi  lō‘ihi no ka maka‘u ia Puali‘i. ‘Ōlelo akula ‘o Puali‘i  iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o: “‘Ē\! Eia ke ko‘ilipi ma ku‘u  lima, he mea ‘o‘oki no kō po‘o i kēia lā, a moku kō po‘o, a laila, kālua me ka ‘uala, a ‘ai iho a‘u ma mua, a laila, noa.” ‘A‘ohe ho‘olohe mai ‘o  Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kēia mau ‘ōlelo a Puali‘i, a laila,  ‘ōlelo hou ‘o Puali‘i, ‘o ka lua ia. Mākaukau ‘o  Puali‘i e ‘o‘oki ia Nāmakaokapāo‘o i ke ko‘ilipi, i ia  wā i pule ai ‘o Nāmakaokapāo‘o i kāna pule make  no Puali‘i. Penei ua pule lā:  Aloha wale ka maka o a‘u wahi pāo‘o, E hapupu‘u, e hāpāpa‘a mai nei,  E ‘ai paha, e waiho paha,  E waiho paha Nākukui‘aimakaokalani,  ‘O Kukui‘aimakaokalani kēlā,  ‘O ku‘u wahi aikāne kēia,  ‘O Nāmakaokai‘a ke ali‘i nui o Hawai‘i,  E he‘e lā, e he‘e ka hōhē wale,  ‘O kānaka nō me ka ihe,  ‘O ka ihe nō me ka pahu,  Make nō iā Nāmakaokapāo‘o.
llama-3.3-70B-Instruct_exl2_6.0bpw-maui_: Puali'i took the axe and went until he reached the middle and found Nāmakaokapāo'o kneeling and cooking four sweet potatoes on the fire. All the children saw and ran to the place and stood before Puali'i. Puali'i said to Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Here is the axe in my hand, to cut your head off today, and your head will be cooked with the sweet potatoes, and I will eat first, and then it will be free." Nāmakaokapāo'o did not listen to Puali'i's words, and Puali'i spoke again, of the pit. Puali'i was ready to kill Nāmakaokapāo'o with the axe, at the time when Nāmakaokapāo'o was praying his death prayer for Puali'i. The prayer was as follows: My dear Nākukui'aimakaokalani, who is Kukui'aimakaokalani, my lover, and Nāmakaokai'a, the great chief of Hawai'i, let the anger go, let the foolishness go, a person with a spear, a spear with a drum, death to Nāmakaokapāo'o.

• The narrative presents a confrontation between Puali'i and Nāmakaokapāo'o, symbolizing the clash between traditional Hawaiian values and the influence of external forces.
  – This confrontation can be seen as a representation of the cultural transitions occurring during the post-1820 missionary influence period, where traditional practices and beliefs were being challenged by new ideologies.
  – The character of Puali'i, wielding an axe, may represent the disruptive force of change, while Nāmakaokapāo'o, cooking sweet potatoes, embodies the traditional and nurturing aspects of Hawaiian culture.

• The name Nā-maka-o-ka-pā-o'o can be broken down to reveal its symbolic meaning.
  – Nā- refers to the possessive article, indicating a connection to the gods or the divine.
  – Maka- means "eye" or "face," representing insight, wisdom, or spiritual connection.
  – O- is a possessive article, indicating a relationship or connection.
  – Ka- is an article used to indicate a noun or a concept.
  – Pā-o'o refers to a type of spirit or ghost, often associated with the ancestors or the afterlife.
  – The name Nāmakaokapāo'o may therefore signify a connection to the spiritual realm, ancestral wisdom, or the afterlife.

• The prayer spoken by Nāmakaokapāo'o contains significant cultural and historical references.
  – The mention of Nā-maka-o-kai-'a, the great chief of Hawai'i, may refer to a historical figure or a symbolic representation of Hawaiian leadership and authority.
  – The phrase "let the anger go, let the foolishness go" may be seen as a call for balance, harmony, and the resolution of conflicts, reflecting the importance of maintaining social equilibrium in traditional Hawaiian society.
  – The image of "a person with a spear, a spear with a drum" may symbolize the connection between warfare, music, and spiritual practices, highlighting the complexities of Hawaiian cultural expressions.

• The use of numerical symbolism, such as the four sweet potatoes, may hold significance in the narrative.
  – The number four is often associated with the four cardinal directions, the four seasons, or the four stages of life, representing balance, harmony, and completeness.
  – The cooking of four sweet potatoes may symbolize the nourishment and sustenance of the community, as well as the importance of sharing and reciprocity in traditional Hawaiian culture.

• The narrative may be seen as a reflection of social commentary or critique, particularly in regards to the impact of external influences on traditional Hawaiian society.
  – The character of Puali'i, with his axe and destructive intentions, may represent the disruptive force of colonialism or missionary influence, which threatened the traditional ways of life and cultural practices.
  – The prayer spoken by Nāmakaokapāo'o, with its emphasis on balance, harmony, and the resolution of conflicts, may be seen as a call for resistance against the erosive forces of change and a plea for the preservation of traditional values and cultural identity.
raw_response:
<translation>
Puali'i took the axe and went until he reached the middle and found Nāmakaokapāo'o kneeling and cooking four sweet potatoes on the fire. All the children saw and ran to the place and stood before Puali'i. Puali'i said to Nāmakaokapāo'o: "Here is the axe in my hand, to cut your head off today, and your head will be cooked with the sweet potatoes, and I will eat first, and then it will be free." Nāmakaokapāo'o did not listen to Puali'i's words, and Puali'i spoke again, of the pit. Puali'i was ready to kill Nāmakaokapāo'o with the axe, at the time when Nāmakaokapāo'o was praying his death prayer for Puali'i. The prayer was as follows: My dear Nākukui'aimakaokalani, who is Kukui'aimakaokalani, my lover, and Nāmakaokai'a, the great chief of Hawai'i, let the anger go, let the foolishness go, a person with a spear, a spear with a drum, death to Nāmakaokapāo'o.
</translation>

<commentary>
• The narrative presents a confrontation between Puali'i and Nāmakaokapāo'o, symbolizing the clash between traditional Hawaiian values and the influence of external forces.
  – This confrontation can be seen as a representation of the cultural transitions occurring during the post-1820 missionary influence period, where traditional practices and beliefs were being challenged by new ideologies.
  – The character of Puali'i, wielding an axe, may represent the disruptive force of change, while Nāmakaokapāo'o, cooking sweet potatoes, embodies the traditional and nurturing aspects of Hawaiian culture.

• The name Nā-maka-o-ka-pā-o'o can be broken down to reveal its symbolic meaning.
  – Nā- refers to the possessive article, indicating a connection to the gods or the divine.
  – Maka- means "eye" or "face," representing insight, wisdom, or spiritual connection.
  – O- is a possessive article, indicating a relationship or connection.
  – Ka- is an article used to indicate a noun or a concept.
  – Pā-o'o refers to a type of spirit or ghost, often associated with the ancestors or the afterlife.
  – The name Nāmakaokapāo'o may therefore signify a connection to the spiritual realm, ancestral wisdom, or the afterlife.

• The prayer spoken by Nāmakaokapāo'o contains significant cultural and historical references.
  – The mention of Nā-maka-o-kai-'a, the great chief of Hawai'i, may refer to a historical figure or a symbolic representation of Hawaiian leadership and authority.
  – The phrase "let the anger go, let the foolishness go" may be seen as a call for balance, harmony, and the resolution of conflicts, reflecting the importance of maintaining social equilibrium in traditional Hawaiian society.
  – The image of "a person with a spear, a spear with a drum" may symbolize the connection between warfare, music, and spiritual practices, highlighting the complexities of Hawaiian cultural expressions.

• The use of numerical symbolism, such as the four sweet potatoes, may hold significance in the narrative.
  – The number four is often associated with the four cardinal directions, the four seasons, or the four stages of life, representing balance, harmony, and completeness.
  – The cooking of four sweet potatoes may symbolize the nourishment and sustenance of the community, as well as the importance of sharing and reciprocity in traditional Hawaiian culture.

• The narrative may be seen as a reflection of social commentary or critique, particularly in regards to the impact of external influences on traditional Hawaiian society.
  – The character of Puali'i, with his axe and destructive intentions, may represent the disruptive force of colonialism or missionary influence, which threatened the traditional ways of life and cultural practices.
  – The prayer spoken by Nāmakaokapāo'o, with its emphasis on balance, harmony, and the resolution of conflicts, may be seen as a call for resistance against the erosive forces of change and a plea for the preservation of traditional values and cultural identity.
</commentary>
reference_translation: Puali‘i grabbed and adze and went out to the  middle of the patches and found Nāmakaokapāo‘o  cooking four sweet potato vines on the fire. All the  children saw this and ran off and stood a long  distance away since they were so afraid of Puali‘i.  Puali‘i said to Nāmakaokapāo‘o, “Hey\! I got an  adze in my hand to cut off your head today. When  I cut your head off, I’ll cook it in the imu with  sweet potatoes and I’ll eat first, and then, it’ll be  free for others.” Nāmakaokapāo‘o paid no  attention to what Puali‘i said and Puali‘i said it  again. Puali‘i got ready to strike Nāmakaokapāo‘o  with the adze, and at that time, Nāmakaokapāo‘o  prayed a prayer of death of Puali‘i. This is what he  prayed:  How sad for the eyes of my precious pāo‘o fish Heaped up and burnt Should I eat it or leave it aside?  Maybe I should leave Nākukui‘aimakaokalani  alone  It is Kukui‘aimakaokalani afterall  My good friend.  Nāmakaokai‘a is the great chief of Hawai‘i Escaping, the coward escapes  The men with spears  Spears and drums  Killed by Nāmakaokapāo‘o
reference_commentary: **Paragraph 7:**• Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o was in the process of cooking 4  sweet potato vines after destroying the sweet potato  garden. It could be that the 4 vines represent the 4  primary gods of the Hawaiian people: Kāne, Kanaloa,  Kū, and Lono. Sweet potato was one of the most  important food crops that sustained the people (represented in this story by sweet potato and ulua  fish), along with taro (another representation of  humans), and this symbolically could represent the  only esoteric epistemology and lifestyle the Hawaiian  people ever knew in the ‘Ai Kapu era. Cooking the  vine and leaves renders the vegetable edible, while  also killing it, a type of ritual canibalism.  • The words of the prayer offered in chant form  (prosidy) are a type of lament by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o  for Pua-li‘i (i.e. pitying him) and a prediction that Pua li‘i would die a gruesome death despite the fact that  Pua-li‘i was the one about to attack Nā-maka-o-ka pāo‘o with an adze. The prayer essentially says that  enlightenment would consume the eater of the flesh  of men and that the customs of war and hula (i.e.  ʻpahu’) would retreat like cowards, having been killed  off by Nā-maka-o-ka-pāo‘o. This is likely a reference  to Christian ʻenlightenment’ replacing the ‘Ai Kapu  across the Hawaiian Islands.
